question: How do momentum strategies generate returns and what are their risks?

expert_sources.title: Returns to Buying Winners and Selling Losers: Implications for Stock Market Efficiency
An Anatomy of the Trading Process

key_findings.finding: Stocks that performed well over 3-12 months tend to continue outperforming
Momentum exists across asset classes (equities, currencies, commodities, bonds)
Momentum crashes occur during market reversals, especially after bear markets
Behavioral explanations include underreaction to news and disposition effect
Momentum is negatively correlated with value, providing diversification
Transaction costs significantly reduce momentum profits

known_counterarguments.argument: Momentum is compensation for crash risk, not an anomaly
known_counterarguments.validity: Partially valid, but premium exceeds crash risk premium

known_counterarguments.argument: Momentum has decayed as it became widely known
known_counterarguments.validity: Some evidence of decay but strategy remains profitable

known_counterarguments.argument: Capacity constraints limit momentum strategy scalability
known_counterarguments.validity: Valid for smaller stocks, less for liquid markets

must_include: At least one explanation (behavioral or risk-based)
